The unfavorable landing roll has shaped the entire strategic approach: Ceuta, a Portuguese fortress, now becomes essential to the plan.


Don Álvaro de Luna catches your eye from across the table, a slight raise of his eyebrows suggesting there are other matters awaiting attention—the letter to King Duarte regarding staging rights chief among them, but also the approaching diplomatic journey to Florence, Hungary, and Poland. The calendar presses forward; if you mean to depart for Italy before autumn, preparations must begin soon.

"The letter to Duarte will be ready for your seal by morning, Majesty. And the household has been preparing—the Queen has seen to everything." A pause, something almost gentle in his voice. "Travel safely. Castile will be here when you return."


You clasp his arm once, and then you are walking through the familiar passages of the Alcázar, past guards who straighten at your approach, past servants who bow and murmur blessings for your journey. The late afternoon light pours through the windows, catching dust motes in the air, gilding the old stone walls.

The evening unfolds in the particular warmth of family gathered close. Supper is taken privately in the family's chambers rather than the great hall—a rare indulgence that delights the children. Cook has prepared Fernando's favorite almond pastries, and Catalina is permitted a small cup of watered wine like the adults, which she sips with exaggerated dignity. Fernando, almost six, practicing his father's serious expressions but unable to maintain them when Bianca makes faces at him across the table. Nicolás goes first, being youngest. At not quite two, he has little understanding of what tomorrow means—only that father is here now, warm and solid, lifting him into the small bed. He clutches your finger with surprising strength and babbles something that might be "horse" or might be "more" or might be nothing at all. His eyes, heavy-lidded, fight sleep with the desperate determination of the very young. You stay until his grip loosens and his breathing deepens, his small chest rising and falling beneath the blanket.



Juana, nearly three, is already half-asleep when you reach her, but she rouses enough to pat your beard with one hand.


"Scratchy," she announces—the same observation she has made every night for months. Then, with the devastating simplicity of small children: "Come back."


Not a question. A command. The imperative of a child who has never known a world where her commands might go unheeded.



Teresa, four years old, has prepared. She sits upright in bed, a small carved horse clutched in her hands—one you gave her last year, you remember.


"Catalina says you're going to see the Pope," she says solemnly. "Is he very old? Does he have a beard like yours? Catalina says he wears a special hat."


She has more questions—about Italy, about ships, about whether dragons are real—and you answer them all, or as many as you can before her eyelids grow heavy. When you kiss her forehead, she presses the carved horse into your hands.


"For the journey," she whispers. "So you remember."



Bianca, nearly five, is the quiet one—always has been. She watches you enter with those grey-green eyes so like her mother's, and she does not ask questions or make demands. She simply extends her arms, waiting to be held.


You sit on the edge of her bed and she curls against you, her head beneath your chin. For a long while, neither of you speaks. Then, very softly:


"Will you miss us?"



Fernando awaits you sitting up straight, attempting the dignity befitting a Prince of Asturias. He is almost six—old enough to understand that his father's journey is important, old enough to feel the weight of being the eldest son left behind.


"I will be good," he says, the words rehearsed. "I will mind Mother and Don Álvaro and practice my letters and my riding." A pause. His composure wavers slightly. "How many sleeps until you return?"


The question hangs in the air. He is old enough now to count, old enough to understand that the answer matters.



Catalina is last, and she has been waiting.


At seven, your firstborn daughter is old enough to understand too much—old enough to remember her birth mother's funeral, old enough to sense the currents beneath adult conversations. She sits cross-legged on her bed, her dark hair braided for sleep, watching you enter with an expression far too knowing for her years.


"I'm not going to cry," she announces, chin lifted. "Teresa cried, and Bianca almost cried, but I'm not going to. You have important work."


She pats the bed beside her, and you sit.


"Lucia-mama explained about the councils and the kings you have to meet. She said you're building something—like a cathedral, but made of promises instead of stones." Catalina considers this. "I think promises are harder than stones. Stones stay where you put them."


She is quiet for a moment, fidgeting with her braid. Then:


"Papá? When I sang for King Duarte, you looked at me like... like I'd done something important. Not just pretty—important." Her voice drops. "Will you tell me, before you go, what you saw? What you're thinking about, when you look at me like that?"

Catalina is quiet for a long moment, absorbing your words with that particular stillness she has—the one that reminds you, sometimes painfully, of Isabel in her most thoughtful moments.


"Lucia-mama says the same thing," she says finally. "That we matter because we are, not because of what we do." She fidgets with her braid again, working through something. "But then why does everyone care so much about what kings do? If Fernando matters because he is, why does everyone also talk about what kind of king he'll be?"


She looks up at you, genuinely puzzled—not challenging, but trying to reconcile two truths that seem to contradict each other.


"I think maybe..." she starts, then stops. Tries again. "I think maybe you love us because we are. But other people will judge us by what we do." A small frown. "That seems harder for Fernando than for me. I just have to sing and be pretty and marry someone important. He has to be good."


The observation is startlingly acute for a seven-year-old. She seems to recognize this herself, because she shakes her head and some of the solemnity breaks.


"I am going to miss you," she admits, the brave façade cracking just slightly. "Even if I don't cry about it."


She leans against you, her head finding the hollow of your shoulder—still small enough to fit there, though not for many more years.


"Papá? Will you write to us? Real letters, not just the official ones that Don Álvaro reads to everyone. Letters just for us."



When at last you leave Catalina's chamber—her eyes closed, her breathing even, one hand still loosely holding yours until sleep claimed her—you find Lucia waiting in the corridor. The torches have burned low. The Alcázar has grown quiet around you, the stones holding the particular stillness of a household settling into night.


She says nothing at first, simply studies your face in the flickering light. Then she steps closer and takes your hand—the same hand Catalina just released—and holds it against her chest, over her heart.


"Six children," she says softly. "Six little pieces of you, staying here with me while the rest of you rides off to reshape the world." A pause. "I used to think my uncle prepared me for anything. Ferrara was not a gentle education. But nothing prepared me for this—for loving someone so much that watching them leave feels like learning to breathe with half a lung."


She looks up at you, those grey-green eyes luminous in the torchlight.


"I will keep your kingdom safe. I will keep your children safe. I will write you letters full of their small victories and disasters, and I will not burden you with fears you cannot address from a thousand miles away." Her voice is steady, but her hand tightens on yours. "And you will come back to me. Not to Castile, not to your throne, not to your grand alliance—to me. Say it."
